2. Age Group Analysis: The NWSF data reveals that the gender disparity in drowning rates is most pronounced among children and young adults. Boys in the age group of 0-19 years are significantly more likely to drown compared to girls in the same age range.

6. Recent Advancements: Recent advancements in water safety education and awareness campaigns have aimed to address the gender disparity in drowning rates. Organizations like the Royal Life Saving Society UK have implemented programs to promote swimming skills and water safety knowledge among both boys and girls, aiming to reduce drowning incidents overall.

It is important to note that while the assertion holds true based on available data, it does not imply that girls are immune to drowning incidents.
